Brazelton, what do you think?
Absolutely.
Thank goodness.
My children grew up in a house where we have our cocktail at 6:30 everyday.
And they all have gone to AA, they've gone to Children of Alcoholics, but none of them drink.
It's really so irritating to have four children that won't drink with you.
(Soundbite of laughter)
So, you know, you aren't really passing this on.
You're really just giving them a model to take or not take.
And this is the beauty of it and this is what Amy's been talking about.
That sometimes when these kids turn against the model, they're learning more than when they go ahead and model on you.
Mm-hmm.

And the fact of the matter is - and, Amy, you know this well if you're daughter's 17 - after awhile, their models are not just their parents, but their siblings, their teachers, their camp counselors...
And their friends.
I mean, we had better hope that other parents are doing as good a job as we're trying to do, because our children - older teens are very influenced by their friends.
And one of the things we do at home, if, you know - those of us who are trying to be thoughtful about it - is we try to model great friendship behavior and great relationship behavior.

And it doesn't mean that you pick your children's friends, but it means that you -one thing I like about having your friends and their kids over to drink wine is that your kids are seeing that you have friends.
I love that.
That's great.
Thanks to you both.
I guess this is part 78,000 of a never-ending conversation about nurture and nature and how to raise children.
That was Amy Dickinson, who was here with us in studio 3A today.
Nice to see you back in Washington, Amy.
Thanks.

Tony Kushner joins us.
I'm Neal Conan.

This is TALK OF THE NATION.
I'm Neal Conan in Washington.

The trial of Zacarias Moussaoui is in recess today and the jury was absent while Judge Leonie Brinkema held a hearing following yesterday's disclosure that a federal attorney had used trial transcripts to coach upcoming witnesses.

The revelation is not only deeply embarrassing for the government, which is looking for the death penalty for Mr. Moussaoui, it may also mean that the punishment they seek will be taken off the table by the judge.
Joining us to explain the legal background to this and its implications is Carl Tobias, the Williams Professor at the University of Richmond Law School.
He joins us on the phone from his office in Richmond, Virginia.
Very good of you to be with us today.
My pleasure.
Do communications between lawyers and witnesses violate--I understand in this case they may violate a specific court order?
Yes, that's true.

Of course you can talk to witnesses, but the problem here is the judge had a very clear and specific order that said there should be no communication of these transcripts, of what had gone on earlier, or communication between witnesses and any kind of coaching of the witnesses themselves.
Now, I understand some of these witnesses were prosecution witnesses, but some of them were also defense witnesses.
Is it appropriate for a government attorney to get in contact with defense witnesses under any circumstances?
Probably not.
And the defense witnesses, it's interesting, even though they're government employees...
Right.
...are being called on behalf of the defense to help the defense defend its case.
And BRAC sided with the Pentagon in voting to close Walter Reed.
Why is that?
Well, a private in the Union Army made $13 a month, which was easily double what a woman would make as a laundress, or a seamstress or even a maid.
Deanne Blanton is co-author of ""They Fought Like Demons: Women Soldiers in the Civil War,"" and has documented hundreds of women who masqueraded as men during the war.
She says many joined for patriotic and economic reasons.
But once they were in the pants and earning more money and spending their money, they seemed to greatly enjoy the freedom that came with being perceived as a man.
Women at the time of the Civil War couldn't vote.
They mostly depended on men to survive.
In return, they were supposed to devote their time and talents entirely to husbands, children and their extended families.
That was the Victorian ideal.
An ideal, Blanton says, that was mostly aimed at middle and upper-class women, and they're not the ones who went off to war.
The women who went to war, who disguised themselves as men and carried a gun, were overwhelmingly working-class women, immigrant women, poor women, urban women and yeoman farm girls.
Jennie Hodgers part of this group.
She was an immigrant from Clogherhead, Ireland, who couldn't read or write.
By the end of the war, she needed to make some tough decisions about her identity.
If she stayed Albert Cashier, it was more likely she'd find work, keep the friends she made during the war and be part of a respected community of Civil War veterans.
She can have a bank account.
She can vote in elections - and she did, by the way.
Or, if she goes back and puts on a dress and tells everyone that she's Jennie, she has just lost her entire life.
Jennie's decision: to continue her life as a man.
(SOUNDBITE OF MUSIC)
A few years after the war, posing as Albert Cashier, she made her way to Saunemin, Illinois.
She worked many jobs, including a stint as a farmhand and the town lamplighter.
She ended up living in a little house that today sits in a desolate storage building.
(SOUNDBITE OF LAUGHTER)
I'm okay.
Saunemin is a pretty sleepy place: just a grain elevator, a few other businesses and The Tap - the only restaurant and bar along the main strip of town.
Jim Schulz lives on a farm outside of Saunemin.
He and his wife, Dina, have heard the talk around town.
Some people, I think, are looking toward this that it's going to bring us a certain amount of tourism.
And other people, I think, frankly, would rather everybody not know we had a cross-dresser in Saunemin.
I wouldn't like to think that's what puts us on the map, but maybe it is.
The town was not especially proud of Albert.
Cheryl O'Donnell is a church secretary and Albert Cashier proponent.
Since the 1960s, a handful of locals have been trying to save the old Cashier house.
Over the years, the house has been moved to at least eight or nine spots.
For a while it was next to the Saunemin fire station.
They said we're going to burn it for a practice drill, the fire station.
They thought that was funny when they told us that, you know.

Just as the house was about to go up in smoke, it was saved by Betty Estes, the tourism director of Pontiac, the town just down the road, bringing busloads of people over to Saunemin to view Albert Cashier's grave.
And it seems the city board of Saunemin took notice.
The village board has some big plans to finally reconstruct the old house and put it close to the spot where Albert used to live.
(SOUNDBITE OF MUSIC)
It's Memorial Day, and Cheryl O'Donnell has brought me to the cemetery where Jennie Hodgers is buried.
Because Jennie worked so hard to guard her secret, O'Donnell sometimes feels a little guilty.
Unidentified Man #1: One, ten-hut.
(SOUNDBITE OF MUSIC)
Many in town have gathered for a reading of the names - veterans from Saunemin who have served in America's wars.
The Civil War: E.
Brown, John H.
Byrne(ph), Albert D.J.
Cashier.
It's not Jennie Hodgers' name that's read on Memorial Day because it's Albert the town remembers.
And it wasn't Jennie, the doctor sent to an insane asylum at the end of her life, it was Albert's name on the commitment papers.
(SOUNDBITE OF SONG, ""THE STAR SPANGLED BANNER"")
At about the same time, Cashier had become confused and noisy.
Her condition was what today we'd probably call dementia.
But back then, as was typical, she was deemed insane and dispatched to an asylum.
The identity she had chosen was ignored, or as they may have seen it, corrected.
She was placed in the women's ward and forced to wear skirts.
